docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has ordered all 55,000 employees, including uniformed officers, to attend mental health counseling to relieve the stress and strain imposed by the attack on the World Trade Center and its aftermath. The counseling sessions, the first to be made mandatory for everyone in the nation's largest police force, are partly inspired by a similar plan used for rescue workers after the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995 and will be financed by the Police Foundation, a private nonprofit service group for officers, and conducted by mental health professionals at Columbia University.

headline.main: ALL IN POLICE DEPT. FACE COUNSELING
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE NEW YORK POLICE

docs.lead_paragraph: Security and Civil Rights CIVIL RIGHTS -- President Bush defended his decision to establish military tribunals to prosecute terrorists as well as the arrests and detentions of hundreds of Middle Eastern men in response to the Sept. 11 attacks. He portrayed the tribunals and the detentions as necessary byproducts of America's wartime footing. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau's county executive could cut the Legislature's planned 15 percent property tax increase to under 10 percent by vetoing budget fat without triggering a state fiscal takeover, Republican county officials say. And they are urging him to do just that. The state-appointed monitors who oversee Nassau's deficit-ridden finances had set Wednesday as the deadline for the county to complete its budget for 2002 or face state control of its finances.

headline.main: Nassau G.O.P. Wants Gulotta to Limit Tax Increase

docs.abstract: Nassau County, NY, Republican leaders are urging County Executive Thomas S Gulotta to cut Legislature's planned 15 percent property tax increase to under 10 percent by vetoing budget fat without triggering state fiscal takeover (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tonight, after many drumrolls and much confusion, tens of thousands of families in New York will reach a five-year lifetime limit on federal welfare aid. They are by far the largest group yet to face the federal cutoff that has long loomed in the nation's welfare overhaul, and they are among the first to face it in a recession. Already, the city's family welfare rolls have been cut in half by tough rules, work incentives, and a good economy, to about 387,000 recipients. But what the end of welfare means in practice for the startlingly diverse veterans of the rolls remains unclear and sharply contested. The issues range from short-term questions about whether computer errors will keep December rent and food money from needy families, to bigger concerns about whether a safety net designed in a booming economy will work as thousands of low-wage workers lose their jobs.

headline.main: Uncertainties Loom As New Yorkers Hit Welfare Time Limit

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of families in New York will reach five-year lifetime limit on federal welfare aid on Nov 30; they are largest group yet to face federal cutoff, and they are among first to face it in recession; over last few years city's family welfare rolls have been cut in half, to about 387,000 recipients, by tough rules, work incentives, and good economy; what end of welfare means for diverse veterans of rolls remains unclear and is sharply contested; issues include whether safety net designed in booming economy will work as thousands of low-wage workers lose their jobs; states are required by Constitution to aid needy; New York has state-financed safety net to catch estimated 38,000 families whose welfare grants will be canceled, at last 30,000 of them in city alone; additional 13,700 city families are expected to hit their federal time limit over next three months; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: For the second time in three years, teachers went on strike today in this sprawling suburb in Monmouth County, forcing officials to shut the 17 public schools that serve about 10,500 pupils. Late this afternoon, Judge Clarkson S. Fisher Jr. of State Superior Court in Freehold ordered the 1,000 striking teachers and secretaries to return to work. Union leaders, however, said their members would not return to classrooms without a new contract. Negotiations are scheduled to resume on Sunday.

headline.main: Abrupt Walkout by Teachers Closes Schools in Middletown, N.J.

docs.abstract: Teachers in Middletown, NJ, abruptly walk off theirjobs, forcing shutdown of 17 public schools; union leaders say that they will not return to classroom without new contract; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration said today that it expected the federal government to run budget deficits for at least the next three years, confirming that the recession and the costs of fighting terrorism had combined to wipe out huge projected surpluses and complicate the agendas of both parties. The disclosure came hours before Republican and Democratic leaders sat down to begin negotiating over their sharply differing approaches to a proposed economic stimulus package. Republicans continued to press for a new round of tax cuts for businesses and individuals. Democrats insisted that the focus should be on assisting low-income workers and people who have lost jobs.

headline.main: White House Says It Expects At Least 3 Years of Deficits

docs.lead_paragraph: The final collapse of Enron amounted to something that few living Americans have ever seen: a bank run like those in the days before deposit insurance. Enron appeared to become a wildly successful company by creating a new, largely unregulated financial business, that of energy trading. That business ran on credit, and required suppliers and users of energy to sign contracts that called on Enron to meet obligations months or years later.

headline.main: A Big Fall Evoking Nasty Old Memories Of a Run on a Bank

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris Market Place column likens Enron's collapse to run on bank in days before deposit insurance; sees it as reminder for big players in unregulated markets that their financial health must be beyond doubt because they lack insurance to reassure customers when rumors spread (M)
docs.snippet: The final collapse of Enron amounted to something that few living Americans have ever seen: a bank run like those in the days before deposit insurance.    Enron appeared to become a wildly successful company by creating a new, largely unregulated...

docs.lead_paragraph: Economic conditions were still sluggish in recent weeks as the economy felt the aftereffects of the Sept. 11 attacks, according to a Federal Reserve report released today. ''Reports from the Federal Reserve districts indicate that economic activity generally remained soft in October and the first half of November,'' the Fed said in its report, known as the beige book, a snapshot of the economy based on reports from the Fed's 12 regional banks.

headline.main: Fed's Survey Finds Few Signs of Relief From Jolt to Economy

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve reports very few signs of bettered economic conditions since Sept 11 attacks on US by terrorists; slowdown deepens in majority of areas studied; job markets show further weakening; map (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A nanny on the Upper East Side had her work schedule cut to three days a week from five because the wife in the household lost her job on Wall Street. Limousine drivers complain of carrying fewer passengers and earning 40 percent less than they did before. At many top restaurants, waiters are working just three days a week instead of five. And bellhops at Manhattan's five-star hotels say their tips, which often account for half their income, have plummeted by half.

headline.main: As the Rich Do Without Extras, Service Workers Do Without

docs.abstract: Service workers, part of huge yet largely overlooked segment of New York City's economy, are suffering economically since Sept 11 terror attacks; while many remain employed, shrunken incomes will add to city's steep economic losses as their spending power decreases; declining incomes will also effect tax revenues photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Hot Pursuit MORE AFGHAN BASES -- The commander of American forces in Afghanistan said the United States might establish more makeshift bases inside the country, making it easier to dispatch marines and Army soldiers quickly wherever they are needed in the intensifying hunt for leaders and fighters of the Taliban and Al Qaeda. A1
